Barry et al,
Good idea, the images of the nagamaki and Akasaka tsuba are at:

http://s1201.photobucket.com/albums/bb354/alanbale/

Alan



  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Barry Thomas 
  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Saturday, July 23, 2011 5:04 AM
  Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Nagamaki


    
  Listeros,
  An American collector of my acquaintance once had a Shinto wakizashi with 
  ububa. It had gone straight from the forge to the Shrine and was still in 
  shiratogi. Alan's find is indeed remarkable, and thank you for sharing 
  Alan. If I might comment, like David Zincavage I've been unhappy with the 
  esnips protocol for looking at photos on their website. Alan, if you would 
  care to upload them to a yahoo folder or http://photobucket.com/ I would 
  love to see them. The last time I used it Photobucker required you to 
  create an account, but that is all.

  Regards,
  Barry Thomas.

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: "abale.vossnet.co.uk" <abale@...>
  To: "Nihonto Study" <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
  Sent: Saturday, July 23, 2011 4:39 AM
  Subject: [nihontostudy] Nagamaki

  Members of the list have rightly been sceptical of my find as it is almost 
  unheard of in the West, if I had not seen it myself I would not have 
  believed it either. I have seen many swords with Muromachi/Momoyama style 
  koshirae over the years, but 99.9% have been 19th c. swords in retro style. 
  Two exceptions come to mind: Victor Harris and I catalogued the blades in 
  the Museum of Japanese Sword Fittings in Tokyo for Christie's in '05. In 
  that collection was a Momoyama tachi koshirae that was later sold in NY, the 
  other was an itomaki tachi made for an Ikeda Daimyo in Christie's London. 
  Victor has seen this nagamaki and agrees that it is 16th c.

  I think this weapon is the first of a number of identical contract pieces 
  for an armoury, as it is numbered '1' as are one seppa, the fuchi and the 
  tsuka in ink under the fuchi, it is utilitarian, with thin yamagane mounts 
  and low quality lacquer, the nakago-ana are not well made. The long ububa 
  can be accounted for by its lack of use, it may have been polished only once 
  or twice then stored for a very long time, this would account for its fairly 
  good condition apart from the leather tsuka binding shrinking and being 
  attacked by insects.

  It may look like a sword but it has the thick saya of a polearm, no kurikata 
  and the tsuka is 21.5" long.

  As I stated in my earlier post it weighs around 6lbs, this is not something 
  one would want as a personal weapon, it is too heavy and awkward to carry 
  and I think would only be useful in battle.
